description: Develop essential reasoning skills, identify logical fallacies, and learn to construct and evaluate arguments effectively.

lessons.title: Introduction to Critical Thinking
lessons.description: What is critical thinking and why does it matter?

sections.content: Critical thinking is the ability to analyze information objectively and make reasoned judgments. It's one of the most valuable skills you can develop for academic success and life.

lessons.title: Arguments and Reasoning
lessons.description: Understanding premises, conclusions, and valid reasoning

sections.content: An argument consists of premises (reasons) that support a conclusion. Understanding this structure is essential for both constructing and evaluating arguments.
A good argument has true premises that actually support the conclusion. Both structure and content matter!
Deductive arguments, when valid and sound, provide absolute certainty. If the premises are true, the conclusion must be true.

lessons.title: Inductive Reasoning
lessons.description: Arguments based on probability and patterns

sections.content: Inductive reasoning draws probable conclusions from observations and patterns. It's the foundation of scientific thinking and everyday decision-making.

lessons.title: Logical Fallacies
lessons.description: Common errors in reasoning and how to spot them

sections.content: Logical fallacies are errors in reasoning that undermine arguments. Learning to identify them helps you think more clearly and avoid being misled.

items: Ad hominem: Attacking the person, not the argument
Straw man: Misrepresenting an opponent's position
False dilemma: Presenting only two options when more exist
Appeal to authority: Trusting claims based on who said them
Slippery slope: Assuming one thing will inevitably lead to another
Hasty generalization: Drawing conclusions from insufficient evidence

lessons.title: Evaluating Evidence and Sources
lessons.description: Assessing credibility and reliability of information

sections.content: In the age of information overload, knowing how to evaluate sources and evidence is crucial. Not all information is created equal.

lessons.title: Critical Thinking in Practice
lessons.description: Applying critical thinking to real-world situations

sections.content: Critical thinking isn't just an academic exerciseâ€”it's a practical tool for making better decisions, solving problems, and understanding the world.
Congratulations! You now have the tools to think more clearly, argue more effectively, and make better decisions.
